title: Central Limit Theorem
text:
Warning: package 'patchwork' was built under R version 4.4.3



Introduction
The Central Limit Theorem states that, for a large enough sample size, the distribution of the sample mean becomes approximately normal—even if the population distribution is not—so long as the samples are independent and come from a population with finite variance.
To demonstrate this, 3 different population (N = 100000) following normal, uniform and right-skewed distribution were simulated and summary statistics computed (Figure 1).








Figure 1: Simulated populations and coresposnding summary statistics, μ - population mean and σ - population standard deviation





From the simulated populations, repeated sampling was carried out. For every distribution, 1000 samples were drawn at each of the following sizes: n = 3, 5, 10, and 20. For each sample, the mean was computed, and the resulting sampling distributions were visualized (Figure 2).








Figure 2: Distribution of simulated populations (top row): normal, right-skewed, and uniform. Each subsequent row shows the sampling distribution of the sample mean based on 1,000 samples drawn from the corresponding population. Sample sizes increase by row: second row: n = 3, third row: n = 5, fourth row: n = 10, and fifth row: n = 20. μ, population mean; μ ± σ, population standard deviation; x̄, sample mean ; x̄ ± S.E.M, standard error of the mean





As the sample size increased, the distributions of sample means became increasingly normal, consistent with the Central Limit Theorem—even when the underlying populations were not normally distributed.
